clinical_study.brief_title: Perioperative Blood Pressures and Chronic Hypertension
clinical_study.official_title: Predicting Blood Pressure Control Among Surgical Patients and Understanding Their Perspectives on Hypertension, Primary Care Access, and Medication Adherence

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to assess the performance of a clinical prediction model in predicting home blood pressure readings among ambulatory surgical patients. It also aims to measure the association between home blood pressures and patient perspectives on blood pressure control.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.description: To measure the performance of our model for predicting elevated post operative blood pressure by assessing calibration and discrimination of our clinical prediction model to correctly predict the presence of elevated blood pressure in our validation cohort.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Assessment of perspectives occurs an average of 2 weeks after enrollment.
secondary_outcome.description: The association between post operative blood pressure status and patient self-reported blood pressure control, perceived availability of primary care services, and medication adherence.

study_pop.textblock: Ambulatory surgical patients >= 21 years of age presenting for surgery to a tertiary care Veterans Health Administration surgery center.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Ambulatory patients >= 21 years of age presenting for surgery to a tertiary care VHA surgery center.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability or unwillingness to independently operate a home blood pressure monitor.
